Colin, I can see how the idea of adding complexity into the fitness funct=
ion and incrementally restricting/unrestricting it could improve over a reg=
ular fitness function in some problems.  However, it would be interesting t=
o look closely at how it affects internal population dynamics over time.  O=
ne risk of penalizing complexity in fitness explicitly is that you will cre=
ate niches for mediocre individuals who are simple.  These individuals can =
subsist by outperforming (in fitness) individuals of higher complexity who =
are actually trying to solve the problem but do so poorly.  So it can cause=
 some of your resources to be allocated to strategies that have little to d=
o with anything interesting.  One of my inspirations for complexification i=
n NEAT was to introduce a heuristic that aims for the right complexity with=
out needing to make complexity part of fitness.

However, since you are tal=
king about changing such a penalty over time, that makes the dynamics more =
complex and is more interesting than a simple complexity penalty alone.  So=
 my overall concern above does not necessarily apply to the same extent.  Y=
et what I wonder is whether you observe transient pockets of simpletons tha=
t mainly survive by doing nothing and just being simple.  Of course, other =
benefits that you cite may in practice overshadow the cost of such a concer=
n.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <colin.green1@...> wrote:=

> This is an idea I've been thinking about for a while. Consider a
> fit=
ness landscape with local maxima that we tend to get stuck in. NEAT
> gives=
 us some ways of getting out of the local high points:
> 
> 1) Speciation. =
Maintains multiple search 'areas' on teh landscape and
> balances search ef=
fort between them. However, speciation by itself
> doesn't provide a means =
of discovering new promising areas on the
> landscape.
> 2) Random mutation=
s. Allow us to 'hop' to new but relatively proximate
> points on the landsc=
ape, e.g. single new connections/nodes and random
> resetting of connection=
s weights.
> 3) Crossover. Attempts to find new areas, but that are close t=
o both
> parents (typically by searching in some higher dimensional space t=
han
> either of the parents). Hence crossover provides access to a lot of
>=
 new search space by bringing it nearer to our current search
> points(geno=
mes) in terms of 'edit distance'.
> 
> 
> I'm proposing that another way of=
 opening up the fitness landscape is
> to modify that landscape such that t=
he arrangement of landscape
> barriers changes and opens up pathways to new=
 areas, but in a way that
> still leads to promising areas. E.g. One techni=
que I have experimented
> with is to factor the size of a genome into the f=
itness function,
> motivation for this comes from mathematical regularizati=
on - simply
> that simpler models/genomes are more generalised and thus fit=
ter than
> more complex models (depending on the problem domain).
> 
> If I=
 enforce selection pressure against complexity I see the search
> becoming =
overly constrained, but if I lessen that pressure or remove
> it, allow sea=
rch to continue for a while and then re-impose the
> pressure then I've fou=
nd that this to be successful. You can imagine
> that I've removed a barrie=
r in the landscape, some of the genome shave
> migrated to new areas and th=
en I've put back the barriers and the
> genome snow settle into new local m=
axima and continue searching from
> there.
> 
> This idea overlaps with pha=
sed search (alternating between
> complexifying and simplifying) and could =
be framed as an extension of
> that approach, essentially adding more phase=
s or more axes to the
> complex-simple axis. I also think rather than switc=
hing certain types
> of fitness criteria on/off that a smoother transition =
would be a more
> general solution. You can imagine the landscape as undula=
ting and the
> genomes as ball bearings rolling around as the landscpae cha=
nges
> (except ball bearings would follow valleys instead of peaks/ridges).=
